children.text: ***	In keeping with paragraph 10 of General Assembly resolution 77/267, the part consisting of the post and non-post resource requirements (part III) is submitted through the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions for the consideration of the Assembly.
A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

8.I.1	The Office of Legal Affairs is responsible for providing a unified central legal service for the Organization; represents the Secretary-General on legal issues, including in legal conferences and in judicial proceedings; performs substantive and secretariat functions for organs involved in public international law, including the General Assembly and its Sixth Committee (Legal Committee), the International Law Commission and the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL), as well as for the General Assembly plenary meetings concerning oceans and the law of the sea; and performs the depositary functions of the Secretary-General for multilateral treaties and the functions of registration and publication of treaties. The structure and main functions of the Office are described in Secretary-General’s bulletin ST/SGB/2021/1.

8.I.2	The mandate derives from Articles 13, 98, 102, 104, 105 and other relevant provisions of the Charter of the United Nations, as well as the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions, including resolution 13 (I) of 13 February 1946, as the central legal service for the Organization (including funds and programmes and treaty bodies institutionally linked to the Organization). The Office discharges mandates from the priorities established in relevant Assembly resolutions and decisions, including resolution 2205 (XXI), by which the Assembly established UNCITRAL to further the progressive harmonization and unification of the law of international trade, with the Office acting as its secretariat; resolution 49/28 and 52/26, by which the Assembly requested the Secretary-General to carry out responsibilities entrusted to him in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and related resolutions of the General Assembly; and resolution 68/70, on oceans and the law of the sea, by which the Assembly established the Office as the focal point for UN-Oceans. In addition, the Legal Counsel and the Office discharge the mandates derived from resolution 77/321.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

8.I.3	The Office will continue to support international law as the foundation for Member States to interact and cooperate in achieving their common goals. The Office will respond to the needs of its stakeholders and beneficiaries with a specialized legal skill set, institutional memory, credibility and neutrality, while delivering on a diverse and complex mandate.

8.I.4	The Office will respond to the increasing demands for legal services from the Secretariat and other United Nations organs, including through the provision of advice on questions relating to the interpretation and application of international law instruments and on general questions of public international law, to ensure that legal considerations are an integral part of the Organization’s operations and the effective functioning of its principal and subsidiary organs.

8.I.5	The Office will support Member States in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and be a key partner in the United Nations system efforts to advance the decade of action and delivery for sustainable development. The Office will continue to provide input and to support processes relating to the Sustainable Development Goals in which it has a specific mandate, such as Goals 8, 14 and 16. It will engage with stakeholders within and outside the United Nations system on ocean-related initiatives, to enhance the coordination and consistency with current processes and mandates. Similarly, it will support the processes and initiatives related to international law, including those contained in the Pact for the Future.

8.I.6	The Office will contribute to international justice and accountability and continue its role in supporting the Organization’s efforts to strengthen its response to allegations of sexual exploitation and abuse and to hold accountable those who have engaged in such behaviour.

8.I.7	The Office will also support initiatives of the Secretary-General envisioned to increase the Organization’s capacity to deliver, including by providing guidance on the legal aspects of data and innovation and on the policy on data protection and privacy for the Secretariat. The Office will also support the legal aspects relating to the implementation of the Secretary-General’s strategic action plan on addressing racism and promoting dignity for all in the Secretariat.

8.I.8	With regard to the general legal services provided to United Nations organs and programmes, the Office will provide those services to maximize the protection of the legal interests of the Organization and minimize its legal liabilities. The Office will advise on the legal aspects arising from United Nations institutional and operational activities and provide legal services for resolving disputes of a private law character involving the operations of the Organization, its subsidiary bodies and organs, and its separately administered funds and programmes.

8.I.9	The Office will also support the progressive development and codification of international law and the conclusion of legal instruments resulting in the promotion of universal respect for international law, including by continuing to serve as the secretariats of the Sixth Committee, the International Law Commission, the Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Organization, other special or ad hoc committees and diplomatic conferences convened to consider and formulate legal instruments. The Office will disseminate materials on international law through the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law and major legal publications.

8.I.10	The Office will engage in processes relating to oceans and the law of the sea to support the increased participation of States in and the effective implementation and application of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and its implementing agreements. The Office will provide secretariat functions to oceans-related processes of the General Assembly and the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf, as well as the temporary secretariat functions related to the Agreement under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea on the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Marine Biological Diversity of Areas beyond National Jurisdiction, and support the implementation and promotion of the Sustainable Development Goals, in particular Goal 14. The Office will also continue to deliver capacity-building activities on that topic, including for developing countries.

8.I.11	To further the progressive harmonization, modernization and unification of the law of international trade, the Office will ensure the widespread adoption and use of harmonized and modernized substantive private law rules to govern international commercial transactions, strengthen technical cooperation and promote the participation of developing countries in the law-making activities of UNCITRAL. The Office will support Member States in the preparation of universally acceptable legislative and non-legislative texts.

8.I.12	The Office will intensify the use of technological tools and other means to enhance the custody, registration and publication of treaties, including the registration of treaties and treaty actions in line with Article 102 of the Charter, and fulfil the depositary functions of the Secretary-General. The Office will continue to provide legal assistance and advice to States, specialized agencies, United Nations programmes and offices, treaty bodies and other entities on the law of treaties. The Office will also promote and ensure wider knowledge of the law of treaties, including through capacity-building activities and workshops, thereby preventing issues of interpretation and implementation of treaty provisions by contracting States.

8.I.13	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Office will continue to enable the International Law Commission to exchange knowledge, experience and ideas with the President of the International Court of Justice, the African Union Commission on International Law, the Inter-American Juridical Committee, the Asian-African Legal Consultative Organization and the Committee of Legal Advisers on Public International Law of the Council of Europe. The Office will also continue to cooperate with States and bodies established under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. In the fields of the law of the sea and ocean governance and of international trade law, the Office will continue to cooperate with international financial institutions, donor agencies, intergovernmental organizations, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and natural and juridical persons.

8.I.14	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Under-Secretary-General for Legal Affairs and United Nations Legal Counsel, as the focal point for UN-Oceans, the inter-agency coordination mechanism on oceans and coastal issues within the United Nations system, will continue to coordinate the delivery of UN-Oceans outputs and promote cross-sectoral and integrated activities, in particular in relation to the Agreement on Marine Biological Diversity of Areas beyond National Jurisdiction. In addition, the Office will coordinate the work of organizations dealing with international trade law and encourage cooperation among them. The Office will exchange knowledge with the networks of legal advisers of United Nations agencies, funds and programmes.
8.I.15	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Extrabudgetary resources are available to complement the programme budget, allowing the Office to respond to the increased demand for its services;
(b)	Principal and subsidiary organs of the United Nations continue to request legal advice as a main component of the decision-making process;
(c)	Specific mandates relating to international trade law, oceans and law of the sea and others are renewed or confirmed by the competent intergovernmental bodies.

8.I.16	The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The Office will continue to promote gender equality and the empowerment of women throughout all its subprogrammes in the context of the Office’s capacity-building programmes and other related aspects.

8.I.17	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will integrate disability inclusion in its work, as appropriate. The Office will continue to take the steps necessary to ensure that, in the committees it services, delegates with disabilities are provided with the materials needed to facilitate their participation.

children.text: Evaluation activities

8.I.20	An evaluation, conducted by the Office, of the United Nations-Nippon Foundation capacity-building programmes for least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States, as well as coastal African states, in the field of ocean affairs and the law of the sea was completed in 2024 and has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

8.I.21	In response to the results of the evaluation referenced above, the Office is enhancing outreach efforts to increase the participation of small island developing States, least developed countries and landlocked developing countries across all regions, while incorporating perspectives from local communities and integrating considerations related to gender equality into training sessions and research. The Office is also focusing on strengthening relationships with academic host institutions and maintaining up-to-date alumni and host institution databases, while leveraging technological tools to improve the management of applications, address an expected increase in applications and streamline internal selection processes.
8.I.22	An evaluation to be conducted by the Office focusing on the impact of its capacity-building activities on participants is planned for 2026.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Provision of legal services to the United Nations system as a whole
Objective
8.I.23	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure respect for and adherence to public international law, and the development of international justice and accountability.
Strategy
8.I.24	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide legal advice on questions relating to the interpretation and application of the Charter, legal agreements and United Nations resolutions, rules and regulations, as well as on general questions of public international law, including international human rights law, international humanitarian law and international criminal law;

(b)	Advise the United Nations and United Nations-assisted criminal tribunals and their oversight bodies, and other international accountability mechanisms, including on their founding arrangements, statutes, terms of reference and rules of procedure, and on the functions of the Secretary-General thereunder.
8.I.25	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A uniform and consistent practice of the law and, subsequently, in the effective functioning of the principal and subsidiary organs of the United Nations in accordance with international law;
(b)	The protection of the privileges and immunities of the United Nations;
(c)	The effective functioning of the United Nations and entities entrusted with mandates in the areas of international law;
(d)	The appointment and reappointment of the principals of the United Nations and United Nations-assisted international criminal tribunals and other international accountability mechanisms.
Programme performance in 2024

The International Court of Justice has access to a dossier of documents in relation to the request of the General Assembly for an advisory opinion on the legal consequences arising from the policies and practices of Israel in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, including East Jerusalem

8.I.26	On 30 December 2022, the General Assembly, in its resolution 77/247, requested the International Court of Justice to render an advisory opinion regarding the legal consequences arising from the policies and practices of Israel in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, including East Jerusalem. The subprogramme prepared and submitted a dossier containing a collection of all documents that were likely to throw light on the questions raised by the Assembly in its request for an advisory opinion in order to assist the Court in its consideration of the request.

children.text: Result 3: legal and procedural framework for United Nations conferences, including the 2026 United Nations Water Conference to Accelerate the Implementation of Sustainable Development Goal 6: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.I.32	The subprogramme is responsible for ensuring that the necessary legal framework is adopted prior to the holding of international United Nations conferences and also assists with preparatory processes and legal and procedural matters arising during such conferences. The General Assembly, in its resolution 77/334, decided to convene the 2026 United Nations Water Conference to Accelerate the Implementation of Sustainable Development Goal 6: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all and, in its resolution 78/327, decided that the Conference would be co-hosted by Senegal and the United Arab Emirates and held in the United Arab Emirates.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.I.33	The lesson for the subprogramme was the value in better identifying challenges and best practices during the process of advising on the legal frameworks for such conferences. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will assess past similar examples to identify general cross-cutting issues relating to legal, procedural and operational matters and possible actions to ensure responsiveness to stakeholders and a consistent approach to legal frameworks that properly reflects the status, privileges and immunities of the Organization.

Subprogramme 1: deliverables for the period 2024–2026, by category and subcategory

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – General legal services provided to United Nations organs and programmes
Objective
8.I.36	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to maximize the protection of the legal interests of the Organization and to minimize its legal liabilities.
Strategy
8.I.37	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Assist in ensuring external accountability of United Nations and related personnel, including on internal sanctions and external enforcement action and liaison with national authorities;

(b)	Advise on the legal aspects arising from United Nations institutional and operational activities, including the Organization’s development, technical assistance, peacekeeping, humanitarian and other operations;

(c)	Assist the Organization, its organs or its separately administered funds and programmes by providing legal advice on procurement and substantial contracts and on operational and technical assistance activities of those entities;

(d)	Provide legal services for resolving disputes of a private law character involving the operations of the Organization, its organs or its funds and programmes, including representing the Organization in settlement negotiations and in arbitral proceedings;

(e)	Advise on management issues and matters in the system for the administration of justice, including determining whether to appeal against a judgment of the United Nations Dispute Tribunal, and represent the Secretary-General before the United Nations Appeals Tribunal;
(f)	Respond to requests by the Organization for urgent legal advice arising from humanitarian and emergency situations.
8.I.38	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The full maintenance of the status, legal rights and privileges and immunities of the Organization arising from United Nations operational activities;
(b)	The minimization of legal liabilities of the Organization.
Programme performance in 2024
Successful negotiation of a lease for the DC2 Building

8.I.39	In 2024, the subprogramme provided legal assistance to the Department of Operational Support to support the negotiation of the Secretariat’s lease for the DC2 Building. The subprogramme ensured that the Department secured lease terms that appropriately reflected the status of the United Nations and protected its legal interests.
8.I.40	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 8.I.7).

8.I.45	The Organization enters into a large number of commercial contracts with respect to its operations worldwide. With a view to minimizing the legal risks of commercial contracting, the subprogramme has been providing legal support with respect to commercial contracting for United Nations global operations, including by providing a set of standard contractual provisions, the United Nations General Conditions of Contract, which are recommended to be incorporated into all United Nations procurement contracts.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.I.46	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the current set of the General Conditions could benefit from being updated. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will update the current set of the General Conditions, which was last updated in 2012, to reflect changes in contracting practice.

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Progressive development and codification of international law
Objective
8.I.49	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to progressively develop, codify and advance knowledge of international law.
Strategy
8.I.50	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide substantive support to the Sixth Committee, the International Law Commission, the Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Organization, other special or ad hoc committees and diplomatic conferences in their consideration and formulation of legal instruments by assisting in the conduct of proceedings, rendering legal advice, preparing draft texts of legal instruments, resolutions and decisions and preparing background documents, analytical studies and reports;
(b)	Provide legal bodies of the General Assembly with assistance when considering the use by States of the procedures envisaged under the relevant resolutions of the Assembly;

(c)	Implement the mandates of the United Nations Programme of Assistance in the Teaching, Study, Dissemination and Wider Appreciation of International Law. This includes the planning, organization and conduct of four in-person training programmes, namely, the International Law Fellowship Programme and the United Nations Regional Courses in International Law for Africa, for Latin America and the Caribbean and for Asia-Pacific;

(d)	Further develop, disseminate and maintain the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law and prepare and disseminate major legal publications and information on the legal work of the United Nations;
(e)	Support Member States by assisting the bureaux of the bodies that the subprogramme services in devising and implementing working methods and work programmes that ensure business continuity.
8.I.51	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The smooth deliberations of legislative and legal bodies, the conclusion of draft legal instruments and the promotion of universal respect for international law;
(b)	The wider awareness and appreciation of international law by a wider audience.
Programme performance in 2024
The General Assembly adopted resolution 79/128 and decided to elaborate and conclude a legally binding instrument on the protection of persons in the event of disasters by the end of 2027

8.I.52	Following work undertaken over a period of nine years, the International Law Commission, in 2016, adopted a set of draft articles on the protection of persons in the event of disasters and recommended that it serve as a basis for the elaboration of an international convention. In 2024, the subprogramme provided procedural guidance to delegations in the Sixth Committee, including in its working group dedicated to the topic, which contributed to the successful conclusion of the work of the working group and the subsequent recommendation by the Committee that a legally binding instrument be concluded by the end of 2027, thereby contributing towards the fulfilment of action 15 of the Pact for the Future (General Assembly resolution 79/1, para. 36 (a)).
8.I.53	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 8.I.12).

children.text: Result 2: applications from more States for the training programmes in international law under the Programme of Assistance – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

8.I.56	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the percentage of applicants from States that had few participants between 2016 and 2020 in the training programmes conducted under the Programme of Assistance in the Teaching, Study, Dissemination and Wider Appreciation of International Law reaching 48 per cent for the training programmes held in 2024, which did not meet the planned target of 58 per cent. The target was not met due to a 145 per cent increase in the total number of applicants, from 573 in 2023 to 1,404 in 2024.

Note: For the purposes of this table, applicants are those from eligible States that had fewer than five applicants to and no participants attending the training programmes conducted under the Programme of Assistance between 2016 and 2020.

Result 3: increased access by the international legal community to documentary materials of a legal character concerning the United Nations and related intergovernmental organizations in the United Nations Juridical Yearbook – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.I.58	Pursuant to the request of the General Assembly contained in its resolution 1814 (XVII), the subprogramme has published since 1963 the United Nations Juridical Yearbook, following an outline established by the Assembly. The Yearbook details documentary materials of a legal character such as legislative texts, treaty provisions and judicial decisions concerning the United Nations, legal materials produced by the United Nations and related intergovernmental organizations and selected legal opinions of their secretariats. Available to Member States and the wider legal community, the Yearbook promotes public interest in the legal work of the United Nations and familiarizes the general public with the principles and rules that govern international relations. In 2022, the subprogramme published the 2016 Yearbook.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.I.59	The lesson for the subprogramme was that using internal capabilities for desktop publishing has expedited the issuance of some of its legal publications and contributed to making them available to the international legal community in a timely manner. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will explore ways to further advance work on the publication of the pending volumes of the Yearbook.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Law of the sea and ocean affairs
Objective

8.I.62	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the law of the sea for the peaceful use of the oceans and for their conservation and sustainable use, and as the basis for national, regional and global action and cooperation in the marine sector.
Strategy
8.I.63	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide expert advice to States and international organizations on the law of the sea and ocean affairs, in particular with respect to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 1982, the Agreement for the Implementation of the Provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982 relating to the Conservation and Management of Straddling Fish Stocks and Highly Migratory Fish Stocks of 1995, the Agreement on Marine Biological Diversity of Areas beyond National Jurisdiction, and the work of the General Assembly on oceans and the law of the sea and sustainable fisheries;
(b)	Support the implementation of the Convention and the United Nations Fish Stocks Agreement in respect of sustainable fisheries-related cooperative activities among States and other entities;
(c)	Provide secretariat services to intergovernmental bodies and the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf;

(d)	Undertake capacity-building activities (fellowships, training courses and workshops) relating to oceans and the law of the sea in collaboration with relevant stakeholders, including to promote a better understanding of the Agreement on Marine Biological Diversity of Areas beyond National Jurisdiction.
8.I.64	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	An increased number of States parties to the Convention and its implementing agreements and their effective implementation by States;
(b)	Enhanced cooperation and coordination among stakeholders on ocean and coastal issues, leading to enhanced conservation and sustainable use of the oceans and their resources;
(c)	A better understanding of the legal regime for the oceans and the enhanced human resource capacity of Member States, in particular developing countries, to implement that regime effectively.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced capacity for the conservation and sustainable use of oceans and their resources

8.I.65	The subprogramme, in line with the mandates related to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and its implementing agreements, as reflected in the relevant General Assembly resolutions, most recently resolution 79/144, is continuously expanding capacity-building and technical assistance activities to support developing States, including small island developing States. This includes the training of civil servants and other ocean professionals with a view to enabling them to actively participate in multilateral ocean processes and the implementation of the Convention and related agreements at the global, regional and national levels. Such training activities are needs-driven and developed jointly with the beneficiaries, and cover various topics of strategic relevance to the beneficiaries, including: (a) law of the sea, including the Convention and its implementing agreements; (b) ocean affairs, including best practices, and national adaptations; (c) the 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals, as well as relevant actions and decisions contained in the Pact for the Future; (d) sustainable ocean-based economies; and (e) oceans and climate change. In 2024, the subprogramme expanded these training activities to support more than 95 Member States and more than 500 participants. In addition, over 20 years, the United Nations-Nippon Foundation fellowships have supported participants in advancing to senior roles in ocean-related ministries and bodies and have contributed to multilateral negotiations and national legal and policy developments, for example, in the context of maritime boundary negotiations, climate change proceedings, the development of national legislation and marine spatial planning.

children.text: Result 3: strengthened science-policy interface for the protection of the marine environment and the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.I.71	The Regular Process for Global Reporting and Assessment of the State of the Marine Environment, including Socioeconomic Aspects, was established by the General Assembly in its resolutions 57/141 and 58/240 with the aim of improving the science-policy interface regarding the protection of the marine environment and the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources through, inter alia, the preparation of comprehensive World Ocean Assessments. Following the publication of the first and second Assessments in 2016 and 2021, respectively, the subprogramme is supporting the publication of the third World Ocean Assessment (World Ocean Assessment III), in 2025. The subprogramme will also support the preparations and provide substantive servicing for the fourth World Ocean Assessment, the main output of the fourth cycle of the Regular Process launched in 2024 and covering the period 2026–2030.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.I.72	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need for a customized web platform aimed at increasing outreach regarding past and future assessments, and to provide an interactive interface to writing teams throughout the development process of the fourth World Ocean Assessment. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will implement such a platform and conduct outreach and awareness-raising activities, which were initiated for the first time during the third cycle, to ensure the strengthening of the ocean science-policy interface.

children.text: Subprogramme 5 – Progressive harmonization, modernization and unification of the law of international trade
Objective
8.I.75	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to further the progressive harmonization and unification of the law of international trade.
Strategy
8.I.76	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Serve as the secretariat for UNCITRAL, provide Member States with working papers, draft reports and draft substantive private law rules on international trade, and give advice on and assistance in intergovernmental negotiations and coordinate those activities with equivalent activities of other international organizations in accordance with the UNCITRAL mandate and propose that UNCITRAL recommend the use or adoption of relevant instruments from other organizations;

(b)	Provide technical assistance and capacity-building to Governments, including diagnostic assessments, implementation guidance and interpretative materials, as well as training activities and advice on the enactment of UNCITRAL texts in national law;

(c)	Conduct research and facilitate the exchange of experience among Member States on reinforcing the resilience of international trade and global supply chains, with a particular focus on micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises, and explore possible future legislative development to meet the challenges identified for consideration by the Member States.
8.I.77	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Well-informed, transparent and inclusive deliberations of delegations in working groups and the Commission;
(b)	Governments agreeing on substantive private law rules governing international trade and their reflection in universally acceptable instruments;
(c)	The availability of additional UNCITRAL instruments to harmonize and unify international trade law and to encourage resilience in international trade;
(d)	Increased government use and adoption of UNCITRAL instruments in national law and increased legal decisions on those instruments;
(e)	Increased treaty actions, enactments and legal decisions based on UNCITRAL texts.
Programme performance in 2024
Legal practitioners in the Arab States further equipped to apply and interpret texts of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law

8.I.78	UNCITRAL legislative texts are designed to ensure legal certainty for all commercial parties engaged in cross-border trade. Legal advisers, the judiciary and arbitrators must be well equipped to apply these rules effectively. Ensuring that the texts are uniformly interpreted worldwide is a key element of their success and the harmonization of international trade law. To achieve this goal, the subprogramme launched the UNCITRAL Days programme in 2014, starting in the Asia-Pacific region, to build capacity among academics, policymakers and legal professionals through awareness-raising events with higher education institutions. The initiative was later expanded to Latin America and the Caribbean in 2020 and Africa in 2022. In 2024, responding to requests from practitioners and government representatives in the Middle East and North Africa region, the subprogramme introduced the UNCITRAL Days programme in Arab States. The programme comprised nine events focusing on UNCITRAL texts on arbitration, investor-State dispute settlement reform, e-commerce, the international sale of goods and insolvency law to equip participants to effectively interpret and apply such texts. The initiative generated interest and engagement among government representatives, legal practitioners and industry professionals, since many jurisdictions in the region were modernizing their commercial legal frameworks in order to strengthen their economies. This widespread interest resulted in follow-up discussions with the subprogramme on potential technical assistance for legal reforms, underscoring the programme’s positive impact in the region.

children.text: Result 3: United Nations Commission on International Trade Law considers the relevance of its instruments to climate action – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.I.84	Through legal research and preparatory work, the subprogramme has supported States members of UNCITRAL in examining how the Commission can contribute to the international community’s efforts to combat climate change and mitigate its effects by updating existing private law instruments and developing new enabling legal mechanisms, if necessary. Upon the request of UNCITRAL, two colloquiums were held, in 2023 and 2024, respectively, on this topic.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.I.85	The lesson for the subprogramme, based on the outcomes of the colloquiums held in 2023 and 2024, was the need to strengthen research on the relevance of UNCITRAL instruments to climate action. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will collaborate closely with international organizations, States and other stakeholders to conduct further research, with a view to enhancing support for the States members of UNCITRAL on this topic.

children.text: Subprogramme 6 – Custody, registration and publication of treaties
Objective

8.I.88	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure the transparency of the international treaty framework, wider knowledge of the law of treaties and broader participation in multilateral treaties concluded under the auspices of the United Nations and deposited with the Secretary-General.
Strategy
8.I.89	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Undertake the registration and publication of treaties and treaty actions submitted under Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations and provide timely and accurate information relating to deposited treaties, registered treaties and related actions through the electronic dissemination of treaty-related information on the online United Nations Treaty Collection and the publication of the United Nations Treaty Series;

(b)	Provide legal assistance and advice to States, specialized agencies, United Nations programmes and offices, treaty bodies and other entities on the law of treaties, including final clauses of treaties, the depositary practice of the Secretary-General and the registration and publication of treaties. Such assistance would be provided in particular during the negotiation of multilateral treaties and through the holding of capacity-building seminars at Headquarters and at the national and regional levels, as well as through the elaboration of topical reference publications;

(c)	Fulfil the depositary functions of the Secretary-General in respect of more than 600 multilateral treaties and hold and conduct treaty events, including during the high-level week of the annual session of the General Assembly.
8.I.90	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Improved access to treaties deposited with the Secretary-General and related treaty actions, including information on their status, and to treaties and related treaty actions submitted for registration and publication with the Secretariat;

(b)	The prevention of issues of interpretation and implementation of final clauses of multilateral treaties by contracting States and enhanced familiarity with and understanding by States of the technical and legal aspects of participating in the multilateral treaty framework and registering treaties;
(c)	The entry into force of multilateral treaties deposited with the Secretary-General and the universal participation of States in such treaties.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States have improved access to information on treaty law and practice

8.I.91	Workshops on treaty law and practice increase the awareness and knowledge of representatives of Member States on issues pertaining to the international treaty framework, and facilitate the work of Member States in joining multilateral treaties deposited with the Secretary-General and registering treaties and treaty actions pursuant to Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations. Since 2016, including owing to insufficiency of voluntary funds, it has not been possible to hold workshops at the national and regional levels. In 2023, by its resolution 78/236, the General Assembly invited States and interested organizations and institutions to make voluntary contributions to support the financing of workshops at the national and regional levels, as a complement to workshops held at Headquarters.

8.I.92	In 2024, the subprogramme held two workshops at the regional level for representatives of States members of the Central American Integration System and of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. The former was hosted by the Government of El Salvador and jointly organized with the United Nations Institute for Training and Research, and the latter was hosted by the Government of Singapore and jointly organized with the Centre for International Law of the National University of Singapore. These workshops benefited representatives of 16 Member States in total.

children.text: Result 3: treaties and treaty actions are made publicly available in the United Nations Treaty Series – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.I.98	The subprogramme fulfils the mandate of the Secretariat under Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations to publish in the United Nations Treaty Series treaties and treaty actions registered by Member States and international organizations. Since 1946, more than 76,000 treaties and 130,000 actions have been submitted for registration and publication, resulting in the publication of more than 3,100 volumes of the Treaty Series.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.I.99	Further to an evaluation of its treaty publication process, the lesson for the subprogramme was that the efficiency and effectiveness of the publication process and the editorial quality of the Treaty Series could be enhanced by moving to a full digital workflow. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will develop and upgrade its electronic treaty database with a new publication module to enhance efficiency in the publication process and improve quality control through the development of workflow automation functions to capture internal feedback and lessons learned, track technical issues, identify bottlenecks and facilitate data-driven strategic planning.

8.I.105	As shown in table 8.I.31 (1), resource changes reflect a net decrease of $998,100, as follows:
(a)	Subprogramme 4, Law of the sea and ocean affairs. The net decrease of $577,800 relates to the following:

(i)	An increase of $84,200 relating to the higher provision at continuing vacancy rates for one temporary post (P-3) established in 2025 pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/258, which was subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for newly established posts;

(ii)	A decrease of $662,000 relating to the abolishment of three temporary posts (P-3, P-2 and General Service (Other level)) ($456,700) and the removal of non-recurrent requirements under hospitality ($400), consultants ($43,600), experts ($69,600), travel of staff ($18,600), contractual services ($20,600), general operating expenses ($3,500), supplies and materials ($500) and furniture and equipment ($48,500). The resources were approved pursuant to General Assembly resolution 75/239 to support the fifth year of the third cycle of the regular process for the period 2021–2025;

(b)	Subprogramme 5, Progressive harmonization, modernization and unification of the law of international trade. The decrease of $420,300 relates to the abolishment of three temporary posts (P-3, P-2 and General Service (Other level)) ($414,000) and the removal of non-recurrent requirements under contractual services ($5,700) and supplies and materials ($600) that were approved by the General Assembly in its resolution 76/229 to support the reform of investor-State dispute settlement being conducted by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law Working Group III for the period 2022–2025.
New and expanded mandates
8.I.106	As shown in table 8.I.31 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $26,400, as follows:

(a)	Subprogramme 3, Progressive development and codification of international law. The increase of $7,800 under experts relates to travel costs of the Special Rapporteur on crimes against humanity of the International Law Commission to attend the first session of the Preparatory Committee in 2026 pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/122 titled “United Nations Conference of Plenipotentiaries on Prevention and Punishment of Crimes against Humanity”;

(b)	Subprogramme 4, Law of the sea and ocean affairs. The increase of $18,600 relates to the provision of consultancy services to conduct research and support the drafting of the report of the Secretary-General on an overview of the impact of bottom fisheries on vulnerable marine ecosystems and the long-term sustainability of deep-sea fish stocks, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/145.
Other changes
8.I.107	As shown in table 8.I.31 (1), resource changes reflect a net decrease of $113,200, as follows:
(a)	Policymaking organs. The net increase of $326,600 comprises:

(i)	An increase of $417,300 under travel of representatives to participate in the first part of the seventy-seventh session of the International Law Commission, to be held in New York pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/121;
(ii)	A decrease of $90,700 under travel of staff due to reduced travel provisions for Headquarters staff servicing the International Law Commission secretariat;

(b)	Executive direction and management. The decrease of $3,700 under contractual services relates to the lower standard price of information and communications technology charges for Headquarters personnel;
(c)	Subprogramme 1, Provision of legal services to the United Nations system as a whole. The decrease of $4,500 under contractual services is as explained in paragraph 8.I.107 (b);
(d)	Subprogramme 2 General legal services provided to United Nations organs and programmes. The decrease of $8,600 under contractual services is as explained in paragraph 8.I.107 (b);
(e)	Subprogramme 3, Progressive development and codification of international law. The net increase of $90,100 comprises:

(i)	Cost-neutral changes under posts and other staff costs due to the proposed conversion of two general temporary assistance positions (P-3 and General Service (Other level)) to posts (see annex II);

(ii)	An increase of $99,200 under general operating expenses, which would cover miscellaneous services required to support the conduct of various United Nations regional courses and the United Nations International Law Fellowship Programme;
(iii)	A decrease of $9,100 under contractual services is as explained in paragraph 8.I.107 (b);
(f)	Subprogramme 4, Law of the sea and ocean affairs. The decrease of $519,300 comprises:

(i)	A decrease of $502,500 under travel of staff ($88,700), travel of experts ($5,500), consultants ($127,600) and grants and contributions ($280,700) that takes into account the lower-than-anticipated requests from States in 2024 for national technical assistance relating to the Agreement under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea on the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Marine Biological Diversity of Areas beyond National Jurisdiction, and the planned reduction in the number of capacity-building and technical assistance workshops from five to two;
(ii)	A decrease of $16,800 under contractual services is as explained in paragraph 8.I.107 (b);
(g)	Subprogramme 5, Progressive harmonization, modernization and unification of the law of international trade. The increase of $51,100 comprises:
(i)	An increase of $50,200 under contractual services due to the estimated amount of cost-recovery charges that are not part of the recurring budget of the Office in 2026;
(ii)	An increase of $900 under contractual services relating to the higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside of Headquarters;
(h)	Subprogramme 6, Custody, registration and publication of treaties. The decrease of $10,300 under contractual services is as explained in paragraph 8.I.107 (b);
(i)	Programme support. The decrease of $34,600 under contractual services is as explained in paragraph 8.I.107 (b).
Other assessed resources

8.I.108	As reflected in tables 8.I.31 (2) and 8.I.32 (2), other assessed resources amount to $5,279,100. The resources would complement regular budget resources and provide for the requirements indicated in the report of the Secretary-General on the budget for the support account for peacekeeping operations for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026 (A/79/783).
Extrabudgetary resources

8.I.109	As reflected in tables 8.I.31 (3) and 8.I.32 (3), the Office expects to continue to receive both cash and in-kind contributions, which would complement regular budget resources. In 2026, extrabudgetary resources are estimated at $12,849,700 and would provide for 32 posts (2 D-1, 2 P-5, 7 P-4, 10 P-3, 2 P-2, 7 General Service (Other level) and 2 Local level) and non-post resources, whose functions would include the provision of legal advice and assistance to facilitate the implementation of substantive mandates and to protect the legal interests and minimize the legal liabilities of the United Nations.

8.I.110	Anticipated in-kind contributions with an estimated value of $544,400 would provide for: (a) donated right-to-use arrangements between the United Nations, the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Korea and the city of Incheon regarding the operation of and financial contributions to the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law Regional Centre for Asia and the Pacific ($42,000); (b) other services, such as expert advice from two legal experts, for the Regional Centre ($97,700); and (c) technical assistance, administrative support and other services as a contribution for the World Oceans Day event ($404,700).
8.I.111	The extrabudgetary resources for the Office of Legal Affairs are subject to the oversight of the Office, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.

Executive direction and management

8.I.114	The executive direction and management component comprises the Office of the Under-Secretary-General for Legal Affairs and the Evaluation and Strategic Planning Unit. The component is responsible for the following functions:
(a)	Provide the overall policy direction, supervision, administration and management of the Office of Legal Affairs;

(b)	Represent the Secretary-General at meetings and conferences of a legal nature and in judicial and arbitral proceedings, certify legal instruments issued on behalf of the United Nations, convene meetings of the legal advisers of the United Nations system and represent the Organization at such meetings;
(c)	Monitor the resources of the Office of Legal Affairs to address the changing organizational needs and workload and to improve the Office’s management systems;

(d)	Formulate recommendations to the Secretary-General in interdepartmental and inter-agency bodies, support the coordination of the United Nations Legal Advisers Network and provide legal advice to high-level inter-agency bodies;

(e)	Ensure the consistent monitoring and self-evaluation of subprogrammes and support subprogrammes with the identification, development and review of monitoring and self-evaluation methodologies and practices;
(f)	Coordinate the working groups on monitoring and evaluation and on the Sustainable Development Goals within the Office of Legal Affairs;

(g)	Act as the focal point for information on all aspects of the work of the Office of Legal Affairs, including on capacity-building activities coordinated by the Office, coordinate interdepartmental activities and consult and negotiate with other departments, offices, subsidiary bodies and related agencies of the United Nations system on matters of mutual concern;

(h)	Act as the centre for coordination and supervision of all capacity-building activities, including those undertaken under the United Nations Programme of Assistance in the Teaching, Study, Dissemination and Wider Appreciation of International Law (subprogramme 3), and for the strengthening of the capacity of the Office of Legal Affairs to concentrate the planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of those activities to allow for a more strategic and integrated management of capacity-building efforts, the leveraging of partnerships and the replication of good practices regarding legal technical assistance across organizational units to better assist relevant stakeholders and better respond to requests by Member States.

8.I.115	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Office integrates environmental management practices into its operations. This includes decreasing its greenhouse gas emissions by encouraging the use of videoconference facilities for interviews and meetings, reducing print services and ensuring that all printers are set to double-sided printing and encouraging staff to turn off computers and monitors at the end of the workday.

text: II.	Independent Investigative Mechanism for Myanmar

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

8.II.1	The Independent Investigative Mechanism for Myanmar is mandated to collect, consolidate, preserve and analyse evidence of the most serious international crimes and violations of international law committed in Myanmar since 2011 and prepare files that can be shared with competent investigative, prosecutorial and judicial authorities (“competent authorities”) in order to facilitate fair and independent criminal proceedings in national, regional or international courts or tribunals. The mandate derives from Human Rights Council resolutions 39/2, 42/3, 43/26, 46/21, 47/1, 49/23, 50/3, 52/31, 53/26 and 56/1. In its resolution 43/26, the Council called for close and timely cooperation between the Mechanism and any future investigations by the International Criminal Court or the International Court of Justice. The mandate is further elaborated in the Mechanism’s terms of reference (A/73/716, annex).

8.II.2	The General Assembly welcomed the creation of the Mechanism in its resolution 73/264 and, in its resolutions 75/238, 76/180, 77/227, 78/219 and 79/182, called upon the United Nations to ensure that the Mechanism was afforded flexibility in terms of staffing, location and operational freedom so that it could deliver as effectively as possible on its mandate.
Programme of work
Objective

8.II.3	The objective, to which the Mechanism contributes, is to ensure accountability of perpetrators and justice for victims of the most serious international crimes and violations of international law committed in Myanmar since 2011.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
8.II.4	To contribute to the objective, the Mechanism will:
(a)	Collect and analyse information and evidence regarding crimes within its mandate, including by undertaking investigative missions;
(b)	Provide protection and support services to witnesses and information providers, including through cooperation with national authorities and other partners;

(c)	Develop and maintain a secure electronic information management system that can protect against evolving risks to information and communications technology security and facilitate the analysis of vast quantities of data in multiple formats and languages;
(d)	Share evidence and analysis with competent authorities in accordance with its mandate, including for proceedings at the International Criminal Court and the International Court of Justice;
(e)	Engage in outreach to relevant stakeholders, in particular to victims and witnesses, using various communication tools and civil society dialogues.
8.II.5	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The collection and preservation of information and evidence that can be shared with competent authorities in relation to crimes within the Mechanism’s mandate;
(b)	The initiation of fair and independent criminal proceedings by competent authorities in relation to the aforementioned crimes;
(c)	Greater understanding of the Mechanism’s mandate, work and expected results by all relevant stakeholders, including victims and the general public, in particular inside Myanmar.
8.II.6	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Some relevant Member States will permit the Mechanism to conduct evidence collection and witness interviews on their territory and facilitate the safety and well-being of witnesses and information providers;
(b)	Some competent authorities will seek to exercise jurisdiction over the crimes within the Mechanism’s mandate and such authorities will continue to request information from the Mechanism.

8.II.7	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Mechanism continues to engage with Member States, individuals, civil society organizations and business entities to seek relevant information and ensure support for its mandate.

8.II.8	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mechanism continues to consult with international courts and other accountability mechanisms, in particular in the areas of legal and judicial cooperation, information management systems, investigation of sexual and gender-based crimes, witness protection and support, and development of methodologies and policies. The Mechanism also seeks the support of other United Nations entities working on issues relating to Myanmar to facilitate its activities.

8.II.9	The Mechanism integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The Mechanism will continue its focus on sexual and gender-based crimes and crimes against children, including in the evidence and analysis it shares with competent authorities and through appropriate access to protection and support measures for victims of such crimes.

8.II.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Mechanism will actively ensure appropriate access to protection and support measures to witnesses and victims with disabilities.
Evaluation activities

8.II.11	An evaluation conducted by the Mechanism on the establishment of cooperation arrangements with Member States for the purpose of facilitating the collection of testimonial and documentary evidence in their territory was completed in 2024 and has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

8.II.12	The evaluation affirmed the Mechanism’s progress in advancing numerous cooperation arrangements with a concrete impact on the Mechanism’s efforts, as reflected in results 1 and 3. In response to the results of the evaluation referenced above, the Mechanism will continue regular consultations with States and national authorities, including through regional networks; adopt pragmatic and flexible approaches to negotiating cooperation arrangements, including to encourage greater cooperation by States; and, as necessary, adopt alternative arrangements for collecting evidence. The evaluation will also inform efforts to improve efficiencies in the submission of requests to States to collect evidence in their territory and their consideration of such requests.
8.II.13	The following evaluations to be conducted by the Mechanism are planned for 2026:
(a)	Evaluation of the Mechanism’s methodology for sharing information with national authorities and related outcomes;
(b)	Evaluation of the Mechanism’s witness protection and support measures;
(c)	Evaluation of the Mechanism’s security systems and applications, including their impact.
Programme performance in 2024
National and international authorities utilize diverse formats of evidentiary material to advance ongoing legal proceedings

8.II.14	The Mechanism was established to enable national and international authorities to deliver justice for victims of serious international crimes committed in Myanmar. To that end, the Mechanism has been supporting three ongoing proceedings related to crimes committed against the Rohingya population in Myanmar that are being conducted by the International Court of Justice, the International Criminal Court and Federal Prosecutor’s Office No. 9 of Argentina. To date, the Mechanism has shared with competent authorities over 1 million information items in diverse formats, including witness statements, documents, photographs, videos, audio files, geospatial imagery, open-source materials and in-depth analytical products, on various matters of high contextual and evidentiary value to the ongoing proceedings. In September and November 2024 respectively, the Federal Prosecutor’s Office No. 9 of Argentina and the Office of the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court made submissions to their respective judicial authorities seeking arrest warrants for certain individuals who are alleged to be responsible for serious international crimes committed against the Rohingya. The written submissions phase of the proceedings at the International Court of Justice regarding alleged violations by Myanmar of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide concluded in late 2024 and oral hearings on the merits are expected to begin in 2025.
8.II.15	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.II.I).
Figure 8.II.I
Performance measure: number of evidentiary materials accessed by competent authorities (annual)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: domestic and international authorities have access to evidence that assists in establishing specific crimes and identifying perpetrators – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

8.II.16	The Mechanism’s work contributed to domestic and international authorities having access to tailored, comprehensive and timely analytical products and underlying evidence in diverse formats that can assist such authorities in establishing specific crimes and identifying perpetrators of the most serious international crimes, which met the planned target.
8.II.17	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 8.II.1).

children.text: Result 2: victims, survivors, civil society and information providers engage in accountability processes – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

8.II.18	The Mechanism’s work contributed to 33 engagements with victims, survivors, civil society representatives and information providers, for a cumulative total of 130 engagements, which exceeded the planned target of 122 engagements.
8.II.19	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.II.II).
Figure 8.II.II
Performance measure: number of engagements of victims, survivors, civil society representatives and information providers (cumulative)
Result 3: increased access to evidence with the broadest possible admissibility in national, regional and international courts – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.II.20	Building complex international criminal cases requires forensically reliable and probative evidence. In accordance with best practices, the Mechanism has conducted screenings (preliminary interviews) and detailed interviews with victims and witnesses who have relevant information. The Mechanism has shared screening notes and witness statements with relevant competent authorities, contributing to progress in ongoing proceedings.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.II.21	The lesson for the Mechanism is that competent authorities have greatly valued the detailed witness statements that the Mechanism has taken in person from individuals with first-hand knowledge relevant to crimes. In applying the lesson, the Mechanism will continue to engage with more victims and individuals who witnessed the commission, planning or ordering of serious crimes to collect testimonies. In doing so, the Mechanism will continue to engage with individuals from a wide range of locations and backgrounds in an effort to increase the pool of witnesses in stable security situations who may be available to testify in judicial proceedings. Furthermore, the Mechanism will utilize more culturally informed interviewing techniques and focus the interviews on the core elements of crimes and evidence of the identity and responsibility of alleged perpetrators.
8.II.22	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.II.III).
Figure 8.II.III
Performance measure: number of screening notes and witness statements available for sharing (cumulative)

8.II.30	The extrabudgetary resources under the Mechanism are subject to the oversight of the Mechanism, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.

8.II.31	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Mechanism continues to minimize energy consumption at its facilities, where it installed special external walls with thermal insulation panels to reduce the dispersion of heat, thermal windows with energy-efficient features designed to resist the loss of heat and cold, light-emitting diode lights in all office and common areas, and a heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system with thermostats in all offices and common areas to enable better control of the system. The Mechanism also raises the awareness of its staff on energy-saving practices in the workplace.

text: III.	International, Impartial and Independent Mechanism to Assist in the Investigation and Prosecution of Persons Responsible for the Most Serious Crimes under International Law Committed in the Syrian Arab Republic since March 2011

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

8.III.1	The Mechanism is responsible for assisting in the investigation and prosecution of persons responsible for the most serious international crimes committed in the Syrian Arab Republic since March 2011. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and decisions, including resolution 71/248, as further elucidated in the Mechanism’s terms of reference (A/71/755, annex). The Mechanism has a responsibility to support criminal accountability and in doing so provides support to ongoing investigations and prosecutions in competent jurisdictions. It also generates analytical products that can be shared with competent jurisdictions that either currently, or may in the future, have jurisdiction over the crimes within the Mechanism’s mandate.
Programme of work
Objective
8.III.2	The objective, to which the Mechanism contributes, is to achieve accountability for the most serious international crimes committed in the Syrian Arab Republic since March 2011.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
8.III.3	To contribute to the objective, the Mechanism will:

(a)	Build the central repository through existing or new cooperation agreements and focused investigative work and analysis of evidence within the framework of its structural investigation and in response to requests for assistance from competent jurisdictions;
(b)	Prepare analytical products in the context of projects within active lines of inquiry in its structural investigation;
(c)	Share information, evidence, analytical products and expertise with national, regional or international courts and tribunals that have jurisdiction over these alleged crimes;

(d)	Develop and implement its victim- and survivor-centred approach and integrate a focus on gender-based violence, including sexual violence, and crimes against children throughout its work, as well as addressing broader justice objectives, such as assisting efforts to clarify the fate of missing persons;

(e)	Promote an integrated and inclusive approach to justice and accountability through effective dialogue and coordination, including with criminal justice actors, civil society and other United Nations actors;
(f)	Provide support and protection to witnesses who cooperate with the Mechanism to ensure that they can do so in safety and security;
(g)	Engage with the Syrian caretaker authorities, within the scope of its mandate, and other accountability actors in supporting justice processes for victims and survivors.
8.III.4	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Requesting parties having access to crucial evidence of alleged crimes, stored in a central repository and available for collation and distribution;
(b)	Strengthened investigations, prosecutions and trials by jurisdictions with competence over the alleged crimes within the Mechanism’s mandate;

(c)	Greater accessibility to, and influence over, justice processes for victims and survivors, including those disadvantaged by gender-based and/or age-related discrimination, of crimes in the Syrian Arab Republic;
(d)	The strengthening of the broadest possible range of justice initiatives compatible with the Mechanism’s mandate.
8.III.5	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Entities and individuals will provide and/or facilitate the Mechanism’s access to information and evidence in various formats for inclusion in the central repository;
(b)	Access to the territory of the Syrian Arab Republic will be granted to the Mechanism for operations in furtherance of its mandate.

8.III.6	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Mechanism will continue to request access to a growing number of States for evidence-gathering as well as to cooperate with competent jurisdictions, international organizations, Syrian and international civil society organizations and individuals, utilizing a variety of cooperation frameworks.

8.III.7	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mechanism will continue to cooperate with other United Nations entities working on issues related to the Syrian Arab Republic, including the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the Syrian Arab Republic and the Independent Institution on Missing Persons in the Syrian Arab Republic, in accordance with its mandate.

8.III.8	The Mechanism integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. For example, the Mechanism continues to incorporate a gender perspective into its evidentiary strategies to avoid bias that results in the incomplete or inaccurate recording of harm experienced by females and to ensure that due attention is paid to sexual violence against males.

8.III.9	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Mechanism will integrate throughout its work the experiences and perspectives of persons with disabilities in the Syrian context. This is consistent with its victim- and survivor-centred approach, whereby the Mechanism seeks to bring to light and address the experiences of a broad range of victims and survivors who have been historically overlooked.
Evaluation activities

8.III.10	An evaluation of the infrastructure and capacity needs of the Internet Resources Unit and its effectiveness in supporting analysis and sharing activities (postponed from 2025) is planned for 2026.
Programme performance in 2024
Competent jurisdictions’ investigations furthering criminal accountability

8.III.11	The Mechanism is mandated to support criminal accountability and, in doing so, supports ongoing investigations and prosecutions of the most serious international crimes committed in the Syrian Arab Republic since March 2011 in competent jurisdictions. The Mechanism has supported investigations and prosecutions by sharing information, data sets, witness evidence, evidentiary modules and analytical products with competent jurisdictions.
8.III.12	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.III.I).

children.text: Result 3: an integrated approach for inclusive justice – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.III.17	Meaningful and inclusive justice requires active engagement with victims and survivors to reflect in accountability processes their experiences, perspectives and priorities. The Mechanism takes appropriate measures to respect and ensure respect for the confidentiality, privacy, interests and personal circumstances of victims and survivors, including their age, sex, gender and health. The Mechanism has developed dedicated thematic strategies related to these factors, with the recognition that, without proactive strategies, the experiences of specific groups of victims and survivors are insufficiently addressed in accountability processes. These thematic strategies have been developed and implemented since the commencement of the Mechanism’s work and continue to be further refined as part of the Mechanism’s victim- and survivor-centred approach, as reported to the General Assembly.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.III.18	The lesson for the Mechanism was that a consolidated framework that brings together the different components of its victim- and survivor-centred approach, and its thematic strategies, can enable more coherent and inclusive outcomes in justice processes. In applying the lesson, the Mechanism will utilize a consolidated framework to facilitate enhanced integration of a broad range of experiences, perspectives and priorities of victims and survivors.

Other changes
8.III.25	As shown in table 8.III.6 (1) and 8.III.7 (1), resource changes reflect a net increase of $448,800, as follows:

(a)	An increase of $468,600 under posts to cover the proposed establishment of four new posts: Witness Protection Officer (P-4); Political Affairs Officer (P-4); Information Analyst (P-3); and Logistics Assistant (General Service (Other level)). In addition, cost-neutral changes are proposed, including the upward reclassification of one Security Coordination Officer (P-3) in the Operational Support Section to P-4 and redeployed to the Office of the Head of the Mechanism; the downward reclassification of one Reviser (P-4) to Field Interpreter (P-3) in the Section; and the reassignment of one Legal Officer (P-3) from the Office of Head of the Mechanism as a Data Scientist to be placed in the Information Systems Management Section (see annex II);

(b)	An overall net decrease of $19,800 under non-post resources due mainly to realized efficiencies and a change in the implementation of a number of activities, which has resulted in the proposed redistribution of resources, as follows:

(i)	The proposed decrease of $434,800, under contractual services ($339,900), furniture and equipment ($66,200) and grants and contributions ($28,700), is due mainly to the replacement of investigative software and satellite imagery services with more cost-effective solutions; a shift towards more online training of investigators in lieu of in-person attendance; and the reduced planned travel of witnesses to Geneva because resources will be used instead to cover additional investigative and non-investigative missions to the Syrian Arab Republic;

(ii)	The proposed increase of $415,000, under consultants ($163,900), travel of staff ($89,900), general operating expenses ($143,700) and supplies and materials ($17,500), reflects mainly increased requirements for expertise on various thematic areas, including Syrian law, and planned travel to support additional investigative and non-investigative missions to the Syrian Arab Republic; an increase in rental and maintenance requirements, including the planned installation of a cooling system in Villa La Fenêtre, which houses the Mechanism; and non-post resources associated with the establishment of the new posts.
Extrabudgetary resources

8.III.26	As reflected in tables 8.III.6 (2) and 8.III.7 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $5,167,100. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 20 posts (1 P-5, 6 P-4, 7 P-3, 5 P-2 and 1 General Service (Other level)) to perform mainly the functions of legal support, external relations and outreach, investigation, information management and analyses, witness support, interpretation and security management expertise. Non-post resources will be used to fund witness protection and other activities in support of the Mechanism’s mandate.
8.III.27	The extrabudgetary resources for the Mechanism are subject to the oversight of the Mechanism, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
Other information

8.III.28	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Mechanism is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. The Mechanism will seek to minimize its environmental footprint by participating in energy conservation efforts led by the United Nations Office at Geneva and, where applicable, by the Secretariat, utilizing shared technological services.

8.III.29	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 8.III.9. The nature of the Mechanism’s work means that staff members are often required to travel at short notice, given that they need to be reactive to the schedules of the Mechanism’s sources. The Mechanism continues to enhance centralized monitoring and disseminate a guidance document on official travel containing clear procedures with regard to the travel approval process.

Progressive development and codification of international law
Conversion from general temporary assistance to posts

The proposed conversion of two general temporary assistance positions of Legal Officer (P-3) and Video Production Assistant (General Service (Other level)) to posts reflects the long-term needs for their functions. The positions were established in the biennium 2016–2017 pursuant to the request contained in General Assembly resolution 69/117 to support the United Nations Programme of Assistance in the Teaching, Study, Dissemination and Wider Appreciation of International Law, including the organization of regional courses and fellowships and the further development of the lecture series of the Audiovisual Library of International Law, as well as the availability of its historic archives in the official languages of the United Nations.
