children.text: Independent Investigative Mechanism for Myanmar

table_content.text: Establishment of one Associate Field Security Coordination Officer

The proposed establishment is to address the significant rise in security threats and risks to the Mechanism’s personnel, premises and assets resulting primarily from: (a) the continued increase in serious international crimes in Myanmar and the accompanying increase in the Mechanism’s investigative activities in high-risk areas and engagements with high-risk witnesses, in particular since the February 2021 coup in Myanmar, with more than 28 million information items, including witness statements, documents, videos, photographs and other evidentiary material collected to date; (b) increased workload linked to the Mechanism’s annual civil society dialogue, which required more than 200 personal risk assessments in 2023 and 2024, and approximately four months of preparatory work per dialogue to mitigate complex security challenges; and (c) growing prospects for justice and accountability requiring more robust and proactive security measures in response to new vulnerabilities for the Mechanism as it becomes more exposed to threat actors with significant capabilities to impede the Mechanism’s work and cause serious harm to its personnel.

The Mechanism currently has one post of Security Coordination Officer (P-3). The incumbent would support the Security Coordination Officer in undertaking security assessments in countries where the Mechanism undertakes diplomatic and investigative missions, implementing plans necessary to mitigate security risks and threats and assisting in developing a mission-specific security risk management approach, identifying comprehensive security risk mitigation measures and coordinating closely with relevant Mechanism personnel on their implementation. The incumbent would also maintain regular communication and coordinate with the Department of Safety and Security and host country security counterparts.

children.text: International, Impartial and Independent Mechanism to Assist in the Investigation and Prosecution of Persons Responsible for the Most Serious Crimes under International Law Committed in the Syrian Arab Republic since March 2011

table_content.text: Establishment of one Political Affairs Officer

The Political Affairs Officer is proposed in order to support the Office of the Head of the Mechanism in its political engagements and discussions with the caretaker authority of the Syrian Arab Republic and regional stakeholders. In December 2024, the Mechanism was granted access to the territory of the Syrian Arab Republic for the first time and eight years after its establishment by the General Assembly. While the Mechanism has operated for the past eight years with non-State entities in the country, it now faces a very fluid political landscape that is likely to continue. Given that there are no Political Affairs Officer posts in the Mechanism, the proposed establishment of the Political Affairs Officer at the P-4 level would facilitate a more informed understanding and analysis of the political situation and the impact on its mandate delivery.
Establishment of one Witness Protection Officer

The Witness Protection Officer is proposed in order to support the work of the Operational Support Section relating to witness protection services and ensuring that all witnesses, victims and any others who cooperate with the Mechanism can do so in safety and security. The current and near-term state of affairs in the Syrian Arab Republic, including access to the territory, is likely to increase the number of witnesses, as well as sensitive and security-related issues that need to be addressed in parallel. The incumbent will help the Mechanism not only to manage this level of risk and complexity, but also to successfully interact with relevant third-party actors. The incumbent will also lead and supervise the activities of the Mechanism’s witness protection and support unit, which currently has one P-3 post.

The Information Analyst is proposed in order to support the Investigation and Analysis Section. On the basis of an early assessment of the current state of affairs, it is anticipated that the Mechanism will have access to additional substantial amounts of highly relevant evidentiary material. To adequately position itself to efficiently and effectively review and analyse new evidentiary material in parallel to working on materials already in its central repository, the Mechanism requires additional analytical capacity to plan and execute complex analytical assignments, including the testing, integration and optimization of new analytical tools and infrastructure. The additional analytical research capacity is driven by the growth in investigative activities, given the additional sources of information and evidence that are available in the Syrian Arab Republic. The current Information Analysts are working at full capacity analysing the material that the Mechanism holds in its central repository, supporting 61 open requests for assistance and the Mechanism’s structural investigation. As capacity permits, the Information Analyst will also provide feedback to information providers regarding evidence that they have shared and participate in external engagement events discussing the Mechanism’s substantive work.

The Logistics Assistant is proposed in order to support the Mechanism’s work related to the expected increase in engagements in and substantive missions to the territory of the Syrian Arab Republic. It is estimated that 20 annual missions will take place in the country during 2025 and 2026. The missions require significant logistical arrangements and liaison with the United Nations country team on the ground in several countries (Jordan, Lebanon and the Syrian Arab Republic), a capacity that does not yet exist in the Mechanism. To date, the logistics needs of the entity have been provided by the Senior Administrative Officer, in addition to the incumbent’s regular duties. This is no longer sustainable, given the increase in travel and the complexity of logistics requirements in the Syrian Arab Republic, including arrangements for ground transportation to and from the borders with Lebanon and/or Jordan and within Syrian territory, in order to ensure effective security management throughout the duration of the mission and provide the necessary office and hotel accommodation.
Reassignment of one Legal Officer as Data Scientist (cost-neutral change)

The proposed reassignment reflects the need to strengthen data management capabilities by using existing capacities to the extent possible. The recent change in regime and access to the territory of the Syrian Arab Republic is expected to increase the review and management of new evidentiary materials requiring expertise in data science and management of the evidence pipeline, processing lab and multimedia analysis platform. Given the immense volume and complexity of data collected by the Mechanism, now totalling 281 terabytes, with most of those terabytes representing multimedia content such as video, imagery and audio, the need for specialized data science expertise has become critical. Approximately one third of the Mechanism’s evidentiary records contain complex multimedia data that are not text-searchable without advanced artificial intelligence and data analysis techniques, making crucial evidence inaccessible without the right expertise. The creation of this post will address the long-term need for such capacity and will ensure that the collection, preservation and processing of non-text data is accomplished beyond a mere performative baseline. While the Mechanism’s initial staffing table focused on resourcing eDiscovery, digital forensics and information security, disciplines that remain essential, what has become clear over time is that scalable, advanced data science capabilities, in particular in artificial intelligence and multimodal analysis, are now indispensable for fulfilling the mandate. The work of the Legal Officer post has been reviewed with a view to gaining efficiencies in the Office of the Head of the Mechanism through the redistribution of tasks to three other staff in the Office.
Reclassification of one Security Coordination Officer

The proposed upward reclassification of the Security Coordination Officer from P-3 to P-4 relates to the need to strengthen security management functions in the light of recent access to the territory of the Syrian Arab Republic. In 2024, the Mechanism conducted 72 missions for diplomatic and substantive (witness/victim engagement and evidence collection) purposes. All missions were undertaken in Europe and North America. Since December 2024, the Mechanism has conducted consecutive missions to the Syrian Arab Republic, initially for political engagements. Approximately 95 missions are estimated annually for 2025 and 2026, including 20 to the Syrian Arab Republic. Missions to a country in political transition require significantly different risk and threat assessments for the Mechanism, as well as an escort to the mission area to provide on-site security advice in a fluid environment. In addition, the reclassification of the post to a higher level will improve the responsiveness to requests from the Security Coordination Officer from both internal and external stakeholders and facilitate access to information and participation in high-level meetings. The reclassified Security Coordination Officer will be placed in the Office of the Head of the Mechanism. The cost for the upward reclassification will be offset by the downward reclassification of a post of Reviser (P-4) to a Field Interpreter (P-3), as explained below.
Reclassification of one Reviser (P-4) to Field Interpreter (P-3)

The proposed downward reclassification reflects the increased need for field interpretation. With the increase in investigative activity, witness protection and support, and meetings with civil society organizations and others resulting from the political change in the Syrian Arab Republic, the need for a reviser, working on written texts and documents, has been superseded by the need for additional interpretation capacity. There will be significant opportunities to gain access to evidence through the Mechanism’s sources, including interviews requiring interpretation. Although the translation and revision of texts is still required, it is possible for the entity to outsource this, even when covering subjects requiring experience and recognized proficiency. The Field Interpreter (P-3) (Arabic) is required to provide consecutive interpretation support to the Mechanism’s investigative teams (including witness interviews) and for protection and support assessments and calls in the mission or the duty station, meetings with civil society organizations and secondary translation support as and when required. The Field Interpreter will coordinate the outsourcing of all interpretation needs that exceed the capacity of in-house interpretation resources, require simultaneous interpretation skills or involve different language combinations.
